events.originalText: A hostage crisis in a Lindt chocolate café in Sydney, Australia, ended with police storming the building, killing the perpetrator and one of the hostages.
events.subtitle: Lindt Cafe siege
events.headline: Hostage crisis in Lindt chocolate café in Sydney ends with police storming building

events.originalText: A woman was gang-raped and fatally assaulted on a bus in Delhi, generating protests across India against inadequate security for women.
events.subtitle: 2012 Delhi gang rape and murder
events.headline: Woman gang-raped and fatally assaulted on bus in Delhi sparks protests in India

events.originalText: "Dennō Senshi Porygon", an episode of the Japanese television series Pokémon, induced epileptic seizures in 685 children.
events.subtitle: Dennō Senshi Porygon
events.headline: Pokémon episode induces epileptic seizures in 685 children

events.originalText: Amid an outbreak of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, the British government banned the sale of beef on the bone for human consumption.
events.subtitle: United Kingdom BSE outbreak
events.headline: British government bans sale of beef on the bone amid BSE outbreak

events.originalText: The surrender of Pakistani forces in Dacca, East Pakistan, concluded the Bangladesh Liberation War and the Indo-Pakistani War.
events.subtitle: Pakistan
events.headline: Pakistani forces surrender in Dacca, concluding Bangladesh Liberation War

events.originalText: World War II: Americans engaged Imperial Japanese forces at the Battle of Mount Austen, the Galloping Horse, and the Sea Horse in the hills near the Matanikau River area on Guadalcanal during the Guadalcanal campaign.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: Americans engage Imperial Japanese forces in Battle of Mount Austen on Guadalcanal

events.originalText: Adolf Hitler instituted the Cross of Honour of the German Mother as an order of merit for German mothers with at least four children.
events.subtitle: Adolf Hitler
events.headline: Adolf Hitler institutes Cross of Honour of the German Mother

events.originalText: German-American gangster Herman Lamm killed himself during a botched robbery attempt in Clinton, Indiana, to avoid being captured by police.
events.subtitle: Herman Lamm
events.headline: German-American gangster Herman Lamm kills himself during robbery attempt

events.originalText: Gabriel Narutowicz, the first president of Poland, was assassinated only five days after having taken office.
events.subtitle: Gabriel Narutowicz
events.headline: First president of Poland, Gabriel Narutowicz, assassinated

events.originalText: Vincas Mickevičius-Kapsukas declared the formation of the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic, a puppet state created by Soviet Russia to justify the Lithuanian–Soviet War.
events.subtitle: Vincas Mickevičius-Kapsukas
events.headline: Vincas Mickevičius-Kapsukas declares formation of Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic

events.originalText: First World War: The Imperial German Navy attacked ports in northern England, resulting in hundreds of civilian casualties.
events.subtitle: World War I
events.headline: Imperial German Navy attacks ports in northern England during First World War

events.originalText: English writer Beatrix Potter privately published 250 copies of The Tale of Peter Rabbit (illustration shown) after several publishers' rejections.
events.subtitle: Beatrix Potter
events.headline: Beatrix Potter privately publishes The Tale of Peter Rabbit

events.originalText: Czech composer Antonín Dvořák's New World Symphony (audio featured) premiered at Carnegie Hall in New York City.
events.subtitle: Antonín Dvořák
events.headline: Antonín Dvořák's New World Symphony premieres at Carnegie Hall

events.originalText: Settlers of the Canterbury Association (poster pictured) aboard Randolph and Charlotte Jane arrived to establish a colony at Christchurch, New Zealand.
events.subtitle: Canterbury Association
events.headline: Settlers arrive in Christchurch, New Zealand to establish colony

events.originalText: The first two in a series of four severe earthquakes struck the Midwestern United States and made the Mississippi River appear to run backward.
events.subtitle: 1811–1812 New Madrid earthquakes
events.headline: Severe earthquakes strike Midwestern United States, making Mississippi River run backward

events.originalText: American Revolution: A group of colonists threw chests of tea into Boston Harbor (pictured) to protest British taxation without representation.
events.subtitle: American Revolution
events.headline: Colonists throw tea into Boston Harbor to protest British taxation

events.originalText: Seven Years' War: After a four-month siege, Russian forces captured Kolberg, the last major Prussian port on the Baltic Sea.
events.subtitle: Seven Years' War
events.headline: Russian forces capture Kolberg after four-month siege in Seven Years' War

events.originalText: The last recorded eruption of Japan's Mount Fuji released some 800 million m3 (28 billion cu ft) of volcanic ash.
events.subtitle: Hōei eruption
events.headline: Last recorded eruption of Mount Fuji releases 800 million m3 of volcanic ash

events.originalText: The Parliament of England enacted the Bill of Rights, setting out basic civil rights and later influencing other documents such as the U.S. Bill of Rights and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
events.subtitle: Parliament of England
events.headline: Parliament of England enacts Bill of Rights

events.originalText: Oliver Cromwell became Lord Protector of the Commonwealth of England.
events.subtitle: Oliver Cromwell
events.headline: Oliver Cromwell becomes Lord Protector of the Commonwealth of England

events.originalText: Led by Admiral Yi Sun-sin, the Korean navy defeated a Japanese fleet at the Battle of Noryang, ending their invasions of the Korean peninsula.
events.subtitle: Yi Sun-sin
events.headline: Korean navy defeats Japanese fleet at Battle of Noryang
